keyTakeAways: The construction of a new $250 million White House ballroom has sparked ethical concerns over whether corporate and wealthy donors are using access to the White House as a form of political influence.

A dinner on 15 October 2025 brought together executives from major corporations including Blackstone, Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Coinbase, and Palantir, as well as sports figures like Woody Johnson and the Glazers, to discuss potential donations.
YouTube has committed $22 million to the project as part of a settlement with Trump over the suspension of its account after the January 6 Capitol riot.
The Trust for the National Mall is handling the donations, and contributors may receive recognition such as names etched into the ballroom structure.
President Trump claims he will personally pay for significant portions and has stated that some donors are willing to contribute over $20 million.

Legal experts, including former ethics lawyer Richard Painter, warn that the arrangement could constitute a 'pay-to-play' scheme, akin to past controversies involving Bill Clinton and presidential access.
The ballroom will have a seating capacity of 999, up from the originally announced 650, signaling a major upgrade in White House event capabilities.
The White House argues that the ballroom is a necessary renovation due to the lack of suitable facilities for state dinners and large gatherings.
Despite concerns, no quid pro quo has been proven, and the administration maintains that the facility will be used by future administrations and that soliciting donations is not inappropriate.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The construction of a $250 million new White House ballroom, set to open in 2025, has ignited ethical concerns over whether wealthy donors and corporations are using access to the White House as a means of political influence. While President Donald Trump claims he will pay for much of the project and has hosted a dinner with executives from major companies including Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Palantir, as well as sports figures like Woody Johnson and the Glazers, YouTube has contributed $22 million as part of a legal settlement from the January 6 Capitol riot. The Trust for the National Mall is managing the funds, with donors potentially receiving recognition like names etched into the ballroom. Critics, including former ethics lawyer Richard Painter, warn that this could constitute a 'pay-to-play' scheme, similar to past controversies involving Bill Clinton. Although no quid pro quo has been proven, the scale and access offered by the new facility raise concerns about the intersection of politics, power, and funding.
title: Who is paying for Donald Trump's new White House ballroom?
